questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding memantine? (INICET NOV 2022)
 

1. Its therapeutic effect is due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors.
 

2. It is reserved for moderate-to-severe cases of Alzheimer’s disease.
 

3. It is used only as a monotherapy and should not be used with cholinesterase inhibitors.
 

4. It is given at a daily dose of 20-30 mg/day.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2

 

1. Its therapeutic effect is due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors: True. Memantine is an NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor antagonist. It works by blocking the action of glutamate at the NMDA receptors, which is thought to play a role in the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease.

 

2. It is reserved for moderate-to-severe cases of Alzheimer’s disease: True. Memantine is typically used in the treatment of moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It is not commonly used in the early stages of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. It is used only as a monotherapy and should not be used with cholinesterase inhibitors: False. Memantine can be used alone (as monotherapy) or in combination with cholinesterase inhibitors, such as donepezil, rivastigmine, or galantamine, in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

 

4. It is given at a daily dose of 20-30 mg/day: False. Memantine is started at a lower dose of 5 mg daily and is titrated up to a target dose, which is usually 20 mg/day. Therefore, it is more precise to say that the standard dose is up to 20 mg/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It can be used alone or in combination with cholinesterase inhibitors, and the standard maximum dose is 20 mg/day.

questions.text: Match the following scale types with their lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Matched Pairs:

 

  • 1-b: Collarette scales - Pityriasis Rosea: Collarette scales are characteristic of Pityriasis Rosea, where these scales are fine, peripherally attached but centrally detached, often found around the edge of the herald patch or subsequent lesions.
  • 2-c: Silvery scales - Psoriasis: Silvery scales are hallmark features of Psoriasis. These scales are typically seen as thick, shiny, and silvery white, indicative of excessive proliferation of skin layers, particularly due to parakeratosis.
  • 3-d: Mica-like scales - Pityriasis lichenoides chronica: Mica-like scales in Pityriasis lichenoides chronica refer to the fine, adherent scales that resemble mineral mica, found on polymorphic lesions that can also show hemorrhagic crusting.
  • 4-a: Branny scales - Pityriasis versicolor: Branny scales are a feature of Pityriasis versicolor, described as fine, powdery, and often easily detachable, much like bran. These scales highlight the superficial fungal infection's impact on the skin.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Diseases & special scales:

 

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 4.13, 26.2, 29.15, 40.1-40.5, 50.6, 65.2, 107.3, 109.8

questions.text: Which of the following rules of law are associated with insanity? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both A and B

 

Durham's rule and Curren's rule are laws associated with insanity.

 

  • Curren's rule of 1964 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.
  • Durham 's rule of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both Durham's rule and Curren's rule are significant tests used to determine criminal responsibility in cases where the defendant's mental state is in question.

questions.text: A child presents to you with itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss as shown in the image below. What would be the next best step? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) KOH mount

 

  • The image shows itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss which is suggestive of a fungal infection, commonly tinea capitis.
  • The next best step in confirming the diagnosis would be to do a KOH mount.
  • The potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to visualize fungal elements in skin, hair, and nail samples.
  • When applied, KOH dissolves the keratin in the skin, hair, and nails, leaving only fungal cells intact, which can then be visualized under the microscope.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Fig: Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slit skin smear (SSS):

 

  • This is a procedure mainly used for diagnosing leprosy.
  • It involves taking a smear from the skin, usually from the earlobe, to look for acid-fast bacilli.
  • It is not appropriate in this case where fungal infection is suspected.

 

Option C. Gram staining:

 

  • This is a microbiological staining technique that is used to differentiate bacterial species into two large groups based on the chemical and physical properties of their cell walls.
  • It's not the first line of investigation for suspected fungal infections.

 

Option D. Biopsy:

 

  • While a biopsy can be used to diagnose various skin conditions, it is invasive and not the first line of investigation for a suspected fungal infection.
  • A KOH mount is a much simpler and direct test to confirm the presence of fungus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss suggestive of tinea capitis, a KOH mount is the preferred initial test to visualize fungal elements.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.38, 32.40

questions.text:
What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

Central cord lesions, such as those seen in conditions like syringomyelia and intramedullary tumors, present with a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the anatomical arrangement of the spinal tracts.

 

1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs: This pattern is common in central cord syndromes, where there is damage to the anterior horn cells leading to lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions in the upper limbs. As the condition progresses, upper motor neuron (UMN) signs may appear in the lower limbs due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.

 

3. Bladder and bowel involvement: Central cord lesions can affect autonomic functions leading to bladder and bowel dysfunction, especially in cases of extensive or progressive lesions like intramedullary tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs: This pattern is not typical for central cord syndromes. Usually, the upper limbs show LMN signs due to the involvement of the anterior horn cells, and the lower limbs show UMN signs.

 

4. Posterior tract involvement: Posterior tracts, which carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioception, are usually spared in central cord syndromes. These tracts are located more dorsally in the spinal cord, away from the central lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central cord lesions, such as syringomyelia, typically present with LMN signs in the upper limbs, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and can involve bladder and bowel dysfunction, but they do not typically affect the posterior tracts

choices.text: Making him sit in front row in class

questions.text: A child has bilateral SNHL. Which of the following is not preferred in the child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This procedure is primarily used to treat chronic adenoiditis and otitis media with effusion (OME), which are associated with conductive hearing loss (CHL), not SNHL. Since the child has SNHL, this treatment is not appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) indicates that there is a problem in the inner ear (cochlea) or the auditory nerve. When treating bilateral SNHL in a child, certain interventions are preferred based on the underlying pathology and the severity of the hearing loss.

 

Option A. Cochlear Implant: This is a viable option for children with severe to profound SNHL where the cochlea is affected but the auditory nerve is intact. The implant bypasses the damaged cochlea and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, allowing the child to hear.

 

Option C. Making him sit in front row in class: This is a common accommodation to help children with hearing loss to better hear and engage in classroom activities. It minimizes the distance between the child and the teacher, thus reducing the impact of hearing loss.

 

Option D.  Hearing Aid: This is suitable for children with mild to moderate SNHL. Hearing aids amplify sounds, making them louder and easier to hear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for treating bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as it addresses conditions causing conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program does not include: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) OCD

 

The Mental Health Gap Action Program (mhGAP) by the World Health Organization (WHO) is designed to scale up services for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The program focuses on priority conditions that are of high burden and can be managed effectively in primary care settings.

 

The mnemonic "MESSI DAD" can be used to remember the disorders included in the mhGAP program:

 

  • M: Mental disorders in children (Option A)
  • E: Epilepsy
  • S: Suicide
  • S: Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders (Option B)
  • I: Illicit drug use disorders
  • D: Depression (Option D)
  • A: Alcohol-related disorders
  • D: Dementia

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is not included in the list of target conditions under the mhGAP program, which is why it is the correct answer to this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO's Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) program, which focuses on other high-burden mental health conditions.

questions.text: Based on the depiction in the accompanying image, which model of disease causation is being illustrated? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sufficient component cause model 

 

  • The model of disease causation depicted is a sufficient component cause model.
  • It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present.
  • A disease can have multiple sufficient causes. But each sufficient cause can consist of a pie chart of component causes, a causal pie.
  • One component cause can be a part of more than one sufficient cause.
  • A component cause can be considered necessary if it is a part of a disease's sufficient causes.
  • In the given model, each pie chart represents a sufficient cause made of component causes.
  • Since B is present in all the charts, it can be considered a necessary cause. All the others are contributing causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidemiological triad: An epidemiological triad depicts the interrelationship between the causative agent, the host, and the environment. All of them contribute to disease development. The aim of an epidemiological triad is to identify how to break this relationship and prevent the outbreak of the disease.

 

Option C. PERT model: PERT is used for network analysis. It is a type of quantitative management technique that helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision.

 

 

Option D. Web of causation model: The web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited to study chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sufficient component cause model illustrates how multiple factors contribute to disease causation, with some factors being necessary components in multiple causal pathways.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucor

 

Histopathological staining shows broad septate, hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching, which suggests that it is more likely Mucor.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Aspergillus shows aseptate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Talaromyces: Talaromyces is a genus of fungi that forms septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus that appears as broad-based budding yeast in tissue sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is identified by broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching, and it typically lacks rhizoids, unlike Rhizopus which has nodal rhizoids.

questions.text:
Vaccination against which of the following is recommended in the elderly? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Varicella zoster virus
  2. Rotavirus
  3. Measles
  4. Pneumococcal meningitis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The vaccination recommendations for the elderly typically include vaccines for Varicella Zoster Virus (to prevent shingles) and Pneumococcal meningitis (to prevent pneumococcal diseases, including meningitis).

 

  • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV): The recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is recommended for adults 50 years and older to prevent shingles and its complications.
  • Pneumococcal meningitis: The pneumococcal vaccines (PCV13 and PPSV23) are recommended for adults 65 years and older to protect against pneumococcal diseases, including meningitis and pneumonia.

 

Educational objective

questions.text:
Which diagnostic investigation is utilized to identify the condition characterized by a 40-year-old man displaying abrupt erythematous painful lesions on the trunk and face, joint pain, and glove and stock anesthesia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Nerve examination
  2. Skin biopsy
  3. Slit skin smear
  4. Mantoux test
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

The clinical scenario points to a case of leprosy. The diagnosis of this condition requires nerve examination, skin biopsy, and a slit skin smear (option B - 1, 2, 3).

 

The clinical presentation described suggests a condition called leprosy or Hansen's disease, which can cause skin lesions, nerve damage resulting in anaesthesia, and joint pain.

 

1. Nerve examination: An essential part of the diagnosis of leprosy involves the examination of nerves for enlargement and tenderness, which can indicate nerve damage due to the disease.

 

2. Skin biopsy: A biopsy of the affected skin can be taken and histologically examined for the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

 

3. Slit skin smear:  This test involves taking a sample from the skin (usually from the earlobes or from lesions) and staining it for acid-fast bacilli, which is a characteristic of Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Mantoux test:

 

  • The Mantoux test is used to diagnose tuberculosis, not leprosy.
  • It involves the tuberculin skin test (TST) to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium leprae are both acid-fast bacilli.
  • The Mantoux test is specific for TB and does not directly aid in the diagnosis of leprosy

 

Characteristic clinical features of Hansens disease / Leprosy

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae is the cause of the chronic granulomatous disease known as leprosy.
  • The typical incubation period for leprosy is 2 to 12 years.
  • It frequently manifests as a visible skin lesion, such as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule, or as a numb spot on the skin.
  • The face, buttocks, trunk, and extensor aspects of the limbs are frequently affected by lesions.
  • Skin, cutaneous, and peripheral nerves, as well as mucous membranes, are all impacted.
  • The posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves, are the peripheral nerves that are most frequently affected.
  • The facial nerve is the cranial nerve that is involved most frequently.
  • Both nerve function and hair growth are compromised by the lesions.
  • Burns or ulcers on the amputation limb may also be present in the patients.

 

Additional Information

 

Classification systems of leprosy:

 

Ridley-Jopling classification

 

  • Tuberculoid (TT)
  • Borderline tubercular (BT)
  • Borderline (BB)
  • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
  • Lepromatous (LL)

 

WHO classification:

 

  • Paucibacillary
  • Multibacillary

 

Cardinal signs for the diagnosis of leprosy:

 

 

  • The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy. Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.
  • Mantoux test is not useful in diagnosis of leprosy. This is the test which helps to explain the prognosis of leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic investigations for a suspected case of leprosy include nerve examination, skin biopsy, and slit skin smear to detect the presence of Mycobacterium leprae and to assess the extent of nerve damage.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 28 page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrisons principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 1385, 1386, 1388

choices.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water
Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.text: Which of the following statement is True regarding trematodes? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Of the given statements regarding trematodes, the only true statement is that Fasciola hepatica is seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Fasciola hepatica is the largest and most common liver fluke found in man

 

Habitat - The parasite resides in the liver and biliary passages of the definitive host.

 

Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle and man.

 

Intermediate host: Snails

 

Mode of infection: The definitive host, sheep and man, get infection by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

 

Life cycle-

 

 

Unlike other trematodes and basically all other flatworms, the schistosomes are dioecious, i.e., the sexes are separate

 

Schistosoma Cercariae penetrates through skin, eggs with terminal spine, only snails as intermediate hosts and separate sexes.

 

Praziquantel remains the drug of choice for all trematode infections except fascioliasis, for which triclabendazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma are monoecious: This statement is false. Schistosomes are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes (male and female), which is an exception among trematodes, as most are hermaphroditic.

 

Option C. Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water: This statement is false. Fasciola hepatica infection is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation, not directly through contaminated water.

 

Option D. Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections: This statement is false. While triclabendazole is the drug of choice for fascioliasis, praziquantel remains the drug of choice for most other trematode infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fasciola hepatica is found in the intrahepatic biliary radicles of its definitive host. It is acquired through ingestion of metacercariae on aquatic vegetation, and its treatment of choice is triclabendazole. Schistosomes, unlike other trematodes, are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective tests for hearing do not require the active cooperation or response from the patient and are thus particularly useful in non-cooperative subjects such as young children or those who might simulate hearing loss.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system. It evaluates the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) and the conduction bones of the middle ear, providing useful information about middle ear pressure and fluid presence.

 

Other Option:

 

3. PTA (pure tone audiometry): This is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's response to pure tone stimuli. It is not included as an objective test because it requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. Subjective tests such as PTA, tuning fork tests, and speech audiometry depend on patient interaction and are susceptible to voluntary or involuntary response errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

Gamma motor neurons specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers within the muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha () neuron: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are the main contractile units of the muscle, and are not involved in the direct control of muscle spindle sensitivity.

 

Option C. Beta () neuron: A Beta neurons are sensory in nature, so they neither supply extrafusal nor intrafusal muscle fibers.

 

Option D. Delta () neuron: Delta neurons are sensory neurons that transmit pain, temperature, and coarse touch sensations. They do not provide motor supply to muscle spindles or any other muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma motor neurons (A gamma) specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

 

A positive fungal culture is a minor diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

This classification was detailed by Bent and Kuhn, who established criteria based on their findings of several clinical features important for the diagnosis of AFRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of nasal polyps: Polyps are a common and significant finding in AFRS, often contributing to the blockage and symptoms of sinusitis.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic mucin: A hallmark of AFRS, this refers to thick, peanut butter-like mucin with eosinophils.

 

Option C. Characteristic CT findings: These include hyperdense areas within the sinuses, which are indicative of fungal involvement and mucin accumulation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

choices.text: Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with no significant medical history, who has been using depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) for contraception, presents to the clinic after missing her scheduled injection by 14 days. She denies any sexual activity since her last injection. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago, and she has no signs of pregnancy. What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient regarding contraception? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Give DMPA

 

Explanation:

 

  • As per the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, ideally Inj DMPA (Antara) should be administered 3 monthly as shown in the table below:

 

Follow up of clients (coming on scheduled date for next injection i.e after 3 months

 

 

  • Defaulter: A defaulter is a client who does not return for the next injection on the scheduled date; but comes for it within the grace period i.e. 2 weeks earlier and upto 4 weeks later from the scheduled date).

 

 

Drop out: A dropout is a MPAclient who comes for the next injection after the grace period of 4 weeks is over and more than 4 months have passed since she took her last injection

 

 

In the scenario mentioned above, the patient is a DEFAULTER and hence the Inj should be administered as she falls within the grace period

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UPT before DMPA: This would be appropriate if the patient was a drop-out, i.e. if she had presented > 4 weeks of the date that she had to come on. 

 

Option C. Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier: This approach would be recommended if the injection was delayed beyond 4 weeks. 

 

Option D. Wait till next period: This unnecessarily delays contraceptive protection and is not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient misses her scheduled DMPA injection by up to 30 days, the most appropriate recommendation is to administer DMPA directly without pregnancy testing. 

  • This is because Inj DMPA is known to cause a delayed return to fertlity. 

  • This ensures continuous contraceptive protection while following evidence-based guidelines that balance safety with practical clinical considerations.

choices.text: 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart
4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart

questions.text: What is the dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

 

Explanation:


For fetal lung maturity, dexamethasone is administered to help reduce the risks associated with premature birth by promoting the development of the fetal lungs. The recommended regimen for dexamethasone is:

 

  • 4 doses of 6 mg each administered intramuscularly every 12 hours.

 

This dosing schedule is intended to maximize the benefit of corticosteroids in promoting fetal lung maturity and reducing the incidence of complications associated with preterm birth, such as respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, and the need for ventilatory support.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart: Incorrect. This dosing regimen is not the standard for dexamethasone. The correct regimen involves 4 doses of 6 mg.

 

Option B. 2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart: Incorrect. This regimen is used for betamethasone, not dexamethasone. The standard for dexamethasone is 4 doses of 6 mg.

 

Option D. 4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart: Incorrect. The correct dosing for dexamethasone is 6 mg per dose, not 12 mg.

 

Educational Objective:


For fetal lung maturity, the recommended dose of dexamethasone is 4 doses of 6 mg given intramuscularly every 12 hours.

 

Ref: Page no 2088, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A woman with a history of painful genital ulcers 1 year back has a neonate of 1 week who has lesions on face and body with neurological symptoms. What is the likely infection? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)

 

The question presents a scenario where a woman has a history of painful genital ulcers and has given birth to a neonate who now exhibits lesions on the face and body along with neurological symptoms. This clinical picture strongly suggests a neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is known to cause painful genital ulcers in adults. The virus can remain latent in the body and reactivate later. During pregnancy or delivery, HSV can be transmitted to the neonate, particularly during vaginal delivery if there are active lesions or viral shedding. Neonatal HSV infection can present with vesicular lesions on the skin, eyes, and mouth, and it may also involve the central nervous system, leading to neurological symptoms. Neonatal HSV infection is a serious condition that requires prompt antiviral treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect because it does not cause painful genital ulcers in the mother or the described symptoms in the neonate.

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect because, although it can cause skin lesions in neonates, it is not linked with a history of painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Option D. CMV: Incorrect because CMV can cause congenital infections with neurological symptoms, but it is not associated with painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of painful genital ulcers in the mother, especially when associated with neonatal lesions and neurological symptoms, is highly suggestive of neonatal HSV infection. HSV is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent severe outcomes in the neonate.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in Static Two-point discrimination? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Merkel disk

 

Static two-point discrimination requires a receptor that adapts very slowly to maintain sensation over a prolonged period. Merkel cells are crucial for this function.

 

Merkel cells:

 

  • They are slow-adapting receptors
  • Excellent for 2-point discrimination
  • Have a less receptive field
  • Critical for detecting edges and points
  • Particularly important for tasks like Braille reading

 

The key characteristics that make Merkel cells ideal for static two-point discrimination are:

 

  1. Slow adaptation rate
  2. Ability to detect steady stimuli
  3. Precise localization of sensory input

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Meissner's corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors, making them unsuitable for static discrimination. They are best for fine touch sensations.

 

Option C. Pacinian corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors present at Deep dermis, joint capsule that sense high-frequency vibration and pressure, not static stimuli.

 

Option D. Ruffini ending: Incorrect. While these are slow-adapting mechanoreceptors, they primarily sense stretch and sustained pressure, not precise point discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe
Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.
  • It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block.
  • Management includes
  • Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy.
  • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.
  • Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy: Correct. Medications like azathioprine can be continued under medical guidance, while others are used cautiously.

 

Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction: Correct. Quiescence of the disease and stable renal function are crucial for a successful pregnancy outcome.

 

Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe: Correct. High doses of corticosteroids can be used during a lupus flare, but must be carefully monitored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are not safe during pregnancy for managing lupus nephritis; corticosteroids and azathioprine are safer options.

 

Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thalamus

 

The given clinical stem of a hemi-sensory loss and severe excruciating pain of the affected areas is suggestive of thalamic pain syndrome also known as Dejerine Roussy syndrome. Hence, thalamus marked as B is most likely to be involved.

 

The thalamus is a paired structure, with one thalamus on each side of the brain. It relays sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and regulates consciousness, sleep, and alertness. The thalamus has multiple nuclei, each serving different functions. The ventral posterior nucleus, for instance, is vital for relaying somatosensory information. If the thalamus is damaged, it can lead to loss of sensation, and in certain cases, even cause the burning, shooting pain and abnormal temperature sensations described in the scenario, which aligns with the symptoms of thalamic syndrome.

 

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

Option A.  A- Internal capsule

 

Option B. B- Thalamus

 

Option C. C- Subthalamic nucleus

 

Option D. D- Substantia nigra

 

Lesion in other three structures will lead to motor deficit and in question it is clearly mentioned that there is no motor deficit, only sensory deficit is the which  clearly indicates that the lesion lies in thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal capsule: The internal capsule is a bundle of white matter fibers that separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus). The anterior limb separates the head of the caudate from the lenticular nucleus, while the posterior limb separates the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus. It contains ascending and descending axonal fibers running between the cerebral cortex and the brainstem/spinal cord. Damage to the internal capsule, especially its posterior limb, can cause contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia (motor deficits). However, the woman's motor functions are described as normal, making this a less likely option given the scenario.

 

Option C. Subthalamic nucleus: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the basal ganglia circuit and is specifically associated with motor function. Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus, particularly on one side, might result in hemiballismus, which is characterized by violent, flinging movements of the contralateral limbs. It is not typically associated with sensory disturbances, or the pain described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Substantia nigra: The substantia nigra is in the midbrain and plays a critical role in reward, addiction, and movement. It contains dopamine-producing neurons. The degeneration of these neurons is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease. Lesions in the substantia nigra would primarily produce motor symptoms, such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and tremors. It would not typically lead to the sensory disturbances described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thalamic pain syndrome is caused by the occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches. C/L hemisensory loss, which begins as numbness and escalates to cause intense burning pain in the affected areas, is what distinguishes it.

 

A thalamic lesion results in a breakdown in communication between the brain's afferent route and cortex because the thalamus serves as the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex. The healing process following a thalamic infarct is painful.

questions.text: In which of the following phenomenon, Cell in cell appearance is seen? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Entosis

 

Cell in cell appearance is seen in Entosis.

 

Entosis is a form of cell death that occurs when one cell inserts itself into the neighboring cell, which results in the ultimate death of the invading cell. This creates a characteristic cell-in-cell (CIC. pattern. It plays a physiological role in the elimination of cells detached from a surface.

 

NOTE: Emperipolesis vs Entosis

 

Emperipolesis is a cellular process in which one cell enters into another cell without being degraded or destroyed. This process occurs in various cell types, including immune cells and cancer cells, and is thought to play a role in cell-to-cell communication and immune surveillance. In emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell after a certain period of time.

 

 

Entosis on the other hand, is a cellular process in which one cell actively engulfs and digests another cell. This process occurs primarily in epithelial cells and is thought to play a role in tissue homeostasis and elimination of damaged or excess cells. In entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell's lysosomes.

 

In summary, the main difference between emperipolesis and entosis is that in emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell, while in entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrosis: Necrosis is a form of cell death characterized by uncontrolled cellular breakdown due to injury or disease. It does not involve a cell-in-cell appearance and is marked by cell swelling, membrane rupture, and inflammation.

 

Option B. Apoptosis: Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death involving cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, and the formation of apoptotic bodies, but it does not result in a cell-in-cell appearance. Instead, apoptotic cells are typically engulfed and removed by phagocytes.

 

Option C. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a regulated form of necrosis or inflammatory cell death that is triggered by certain death receptors. Like necrosis, it does not involve a cell-in-cell appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cell-in-cell appearance is characteristic of entosis, where one cell engulfs and digests another, distinguishing it from other forms of cell death.

questions.text:
Which mediators involved in the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Mast cell
  2. Histamine
  3. Neutrophils
  4. Prostaglandins
  5. Leukotrienes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, also known as immediate hypersensitivity reactions, are typically triggered by allergens and involve the rapid release of mediators from mast cells. The early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity involves several key mediators:

 

  • Mast cells (1): Play a central role in initiating the reaction. When IgE antibodies on the surface of mast cells bind to an allergen, the mast cells degranulate, releasing various mediators.
  • Histamine (2): One of the primary mediators released from mast cells, responsible for many of the acute symptoms of allergic reactions, such as vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • Prostaglandins (4): Specifically, Prostaglandin D2 (PGD2), is produced by mast cells and contributes to vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, and increased mucus secretion.
  • Leukotrienes (5): Specifically, Leukotrienes C4 and D4 are potent mediators that cause prolonged bronchoconstriction, increased vascular permeability, and mucus production.

 

Other Option:

 

Neutrophils (3), while involved in various immune responses, are not typically considered mediators of the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity. They are more associated with later phases of inflammation or other types of immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity involves Mast cells, Histamine, Prostaglandins (D2) and Leukotrienes (C4 and D4).

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 377

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

When the surgeon returns the entire hernial sac to the abdominal cavity without reducing its contents, this procedure is known as "reduction en masse" of the hernia.

 

Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a hernial sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Double loop of intestine is within a hernia sac with a tight neck.

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Organs like cecum (right) and sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and are present outside the sac.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia (irreducible).

choices.text: Pleuropulmonary blastoma

questions.text: Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hodgkin's lymphoma

 

Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that works as an immune checkpoint inhibitor by blocking the interaction between PD-1 on the surface of T cell and its ligand present on the tumor cell. It is used in the treatment of Non-small cell lung cancer, Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, Advanced melanoma and advanced head and neck cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: Nivolumab is not typically used for the treatment of retinoblastoma, which is a rare type of eye cancer that usually develops in early childhood.

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: This is a type of brain cancer more common in children. Nivolumab is not a standard treatment for medulloblastoma.

 

Option C. Pleuropulmonary blastoma: This is a rare type of cancer that starts in the lung or pleural cavity, mostly affecting children. Nivolumab is not indicated for this cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor used for the treatment of Hodgkin’s lymphoma, among other cancers such as non-small cell lung cancer, advanced melanoma, and advanced head and neck cancer. It works by blocking the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction, thereby enhancing the immune response against cancer cells.

 

Immune check point inhibitors

 

New:                Nivolumab

Drugs:              Durvalumab

Act:                  Avelumab

At:                   Atezolizumab

Immune:          Ipilimumab

Check:             Cemiplimab

Point:               Pembrolizumab

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

 

In physiological jaundice, there is increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine.

 

Physiological jaundice occurs as a result of increased bilirubin production caused by foetal RB destruction, as well as a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. As a result, indirect/unconjugated bilirubin levels would rise. Increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood cause an increase in the production of urobilinogen, which is found in large quantities in the urine. Urine bilirubin is uncommon in this condition.

 

Both physiological jaundice (indirect) and hepatocellular jaundice (direct) can have increased urobilinogen - just through different mechanisms:

  • Physiological: bilirubin load despite immature conjugation
  • Hepatocellular: conjugated bilirubin reaching gut despite liver damage


 

 

The following indications are suggestive of pathological jaundice and it warrants further investigations for the cause of jaundice.

 

  1. Jaundice appearing in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  2. A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dl/24hr
  3. Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  4. Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  5. Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  6. Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

 

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

 

When the concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20-25mg/dL, bilirubin would penetrate the blood-brain barrier and lead to kernicterus.

 

Phototherapy:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and hemoglobin is 6 g/dL. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia, and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Chest X-ray
  2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
  3. Absolute neutrophil count
  4. Leucocyte antibodies
  5. Platelets
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which includes elevated mean arterial pressure, hypoxemia, and respiratory distress following a blood transfusion. TACO occurs due to fluid overload from the transfusion, leading to pulmonary edema and increased cardiac filling pressures.

 

1. Chest X-ray: This imaging is crucial as it can reveal bilateral infiltrates indicative of pulmonary edema, a hallmark of TACO. It helps to differentiate between TACO and other causes of respiratory distress post-transfusion.

 

2. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) Level: BNP is a cardiac biomarker that is elevated in conditions of increased cardiac pressure and volume overload, such as TACO. Elevated BNP levels would support the diagnosis of TACO, whereas BNP levels would not be elevated in transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), another potential complication post-transfusion that presents with respiratory distress but usually with hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Absolute neutrophil count and 5. platelets are not specific for diagnosing TACO or TRALI. These parameters do not provide information on fluid overload or cardiac stress.

 

4. Leucocyte antibodies are not directly relevant to the diagnosis of TACO. Leucocyte antibodies might be involved in TRALI, but not TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with suspected transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), the best investigations are a chest X-ray to detect pulmonary edema and BNP levels to assess cardiac stress and fluid overload

choices.text: Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

questions.text: Transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) can effectively prevent which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Graft versus host disease

 

Transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) can effectively prevent transfusion-associated Graft-Versus-Host Disease (TA-GVHD). TA-GVHD is a rare but serious complication that can occur when viable T lymphocytes present in the transfused blood product proliferate and attack the recipient's tissues. This is particularly dangerous in immunocompromised individuals or those receiving blood from close relatives where the donor lymphocytes are not recognized as foreign by the recipient's immune system.

 

Irradiation of blood products helps to inactivate T lymphocytes, thereby preventing their proliferation and reducing the risk of TA-GVHD. This is crucial in certain patient populations, such as those undergoing bone marrow transplantation, those with congenital immunodeficiency disorders, and patients receiving blood from relatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HLA alloimmunization: HLA alloimmunization refers to the development of antibodies against human leukocyte antigens (HLA) due to exposure to foreign antigens through transfusions or pregnancy. It is not specifically prevented by irradiating blood products.

 

Option C. Immunomodulation: Immunomodulation refers to the modulation of the immune response by transfused blood products, which is not specifically targeted by irradiation.

 

Option D. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a rare but severe reaction that causes acute respiratory distress following transfusion. It is primarily caused by antibodies in the transfused blood reacting with the recipient's leukocytes, not by the presence of viable T lymphocytes, so irradiation does not prevent TRALI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of irradiated RBCs is specifically recommended to prevent Graft-Versus-Host Disease (GVHD), making it the correct answer for this scenario.

choices.text: Pulmonary infarction
Diffuse alveolar damage
Endothelial injury

questions.text: The most common lung finding in COVID 19 infection is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Diffuse alveolar damage may be seen in patients suffering from COVID-19.

 

COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include:

 

  1. Incipient pulmonary damage in early-stage disease with intraalveolar edema, endothelial necrosis, microthrombosis, and endothelialitis.
  2. Pneumocyte type 2 hyperplasia in exudative phase
  3. Multiple intraalveolar giant cells in exudative phase
  4. Hyaline membranes and solid fibrin deposits in exudative phase
  5. Thrombosis in small- to medium-sized vessels in early-stage lung disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary infarction: While pulmonary infarctions may occur due to thromboembolism, they are not the primary lung finding in COVID-19.

 

Option C. Endothelial injury: Endothelial injury does occur in COVID-19 and contributes to microvascular damage and thrombosis, but it is part of the broader picture of diffuse alveolar damage.

 

Option D. Fibrin clots: Fibrin clots are seen in COVID-19 as part of the coagulopathy associated with the disease, but they are secondary findings within the context of DAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage is the most common and significant lung finding in severe COVID-19 infection, leading to the clinical syndrome of ARDS.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by the presence of specific tumors and physical features. This syndrome is often referred to as "Triple M syndrome" because it commonly presents with three key features: mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid body habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. In addition, pheochromocytomas may also occur.

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) that produce calcitonin. MTC is a hallmark of MEN 2B, making it one of the primary diagnostic criteria for the syndrome.

 

The condition is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, specifically the codon 918 mutation on chromosome 10, which leads to the development of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Café au lait spot: Café au lait spots are not characteristic of MEN 2B syndrome. These pigmented skin lesions are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and, in some cases, tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Parathyroid adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are typically seen in patients with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, not in MEN 2B. These adenomas cause hyperparathyroidism, which is not a feature of MEN 2B.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve gliomas are primarily associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are not a feature of MEN 2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug specifically enhances the inactivation phase of voltage-gated slow sodium channels, helping to stabilize hyperexcitable neurons? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lacosamide

 

Explanation:


Lacosamide has a unique mechanism of action among antiepileptic drugs. It selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels. While most sodium channel blocking antiepileptics (like phenytoin, carbamazepine) act on fast sodium channels, lacosamide specifically targets slow sodium channels. This mechanism helps stabilize hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and prevents repetitive neuronal firing.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Phenytoin: Incorrect. While it does act on sodium channels, it primarily blocks fast sodium channels, not slow sodium channels. It acts by promoting the inactive state of these channels.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Incorrect. Like phenytoin, it acts primarily on fast sodium channels and also affects calcium channels. It does not specifically target slow sodium channels.

 

Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It works primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist and has no significant effect on sodium channels, either fast or slow.

 

Educational Objective:


Lacosamide uniquely acts by enhancing the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, distinguishing it from other sodium channel-blocking antiepileptics that act on fast sodium channels.

questions.text: Which of the following in IgA vasculitis warrants the use of corticosteroids? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GI bleeding

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, typically presents with symptoms such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash. These symptoms are often managed with supportive care and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However, the use of corticosteroids is reserved for more severe manifestations of the disease.

 

GI bleeding: In cases where IgA vasculitis leads to gastrointestinal bleeding, corticosteroids are warranted. This is because GI bleeding indicates a severe form of the disease involving the gastrointestinal tract, which requires more aggressive treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arthritis: Joint pain and swelling associated with IgA vasculitis are usually mild and managed with NSAIDs or supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically indicated for arthritis alone in this context.

 

Option C. Abdominal pain: Abdominal pain in IgA vasculitis can often be managed with supportive care and NSAIDs. Corticosteroids are reserved for severe cases or when there is evidence of significant gastrointestinal involvement.

 

Option D. Skin rash: The characteristic purpuric rash of IgA vasculitis is usually self-limiting and does not require corticosteroids for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are indicated in IgA vasculitis primarily for severe manifestations such as gastrointestinal bleeding, indicating more extensive disease involvement. Other manifestations, such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash, are generally self-limiting and respond well to supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically required for these symptoms unless they are part of a more severe systemic involvement.

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

 

The correct answer is Anomaly scan. This patient has a low risk of trisomy (such as Down syndrome) but a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) based on the quadruple marker test. The quadruple marker test includes measurements of beta-hCG, unconjugated estriol, inhibin A, and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A high level of AFP is associated with an increased risk of NTDs, such as spina bifida.

 

Given the elevated risk for NTDs, the most appropriate next step is an anomaly scan, specifically a targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFA) scan. This ultrasound, typically performed between 18 and 20 weeks of gestation, has a high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting structural anomalies, particularly neural tube defects. The scan is a non-invasive way to assess the fetus for physical defects.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: While amniocentesis can detect chromosomal abnormalities and some structural defects, it is invasive and carries a small risk of complications. Since the concern here is structural (NTD) rather than chromosomal, and the anomaly scan is highly effective and non-invasive, amniocentesis is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): CVS is another invasive procedure used for early genetic testing, usually performed in the first trimester. It is not useful at 18 weeks and is not the best test for detecting structural anomalies like NTDs.

 

Option D. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing): NIPT is a screening tool for chromosomal aneuploidies (like trisomy 21, 18, and 13). Since the patient already has a low risk of trisomy, NIPT is unnecessary and does not address the high risk of NTD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. An ECG was taken in the emergency and was shown. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior MI

 

The patient's ECG shows classic signs of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI). The characteristic features of posterior MI in leads V1, V2 and () V3 include a tall R wave, ST depression, and upright T wave. These features suggest a mirror image of an infarction in the posterior wall of the left ventricle. While definitive diagnosis of a posterior MI typically involves additional leads (V7, V8, V9), the observed patterns in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of this condition.

 

In the provided case, the absence of ST elevation rules out an acute STEMI. NSTEMI and unstable angina can only be differentiated by cardiac biomarkers such as troponins, which are not mentioned here. Acute myocarditis would typically present with non-specific ECG changes and a relevant clinical history, such as a recent viral infection, which is not present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NSTEMI:  NSTEMI (Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction) can present with similar symptoms but requires positive cardiac troponins for diagnosis. The absence of troponin data makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Unstable Angina: Unstable angina presents with similar symptoms but without elevation of cardiac biomarkers. As mentioned, differentiating between NSTEMI and unstable angina is not possible without troponin levels, which are not provided.

 

Option D. Acute Myocarditis: Acute myocarditis would typically present with a history of viral infection and can show non-specific ECG changes, often including sinus tachycardia. The patient's history and ECG findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tall R waves, ST depression, and upright T waves in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of a posterior myocardial infarction.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD21

 

  • The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor on the cell surface. CD21, also known as complement receptor 2 (CR2), is a receptor for the C3d fragment of the complement system and serves as the entry point for EBV into B cells. This interaction facilitates the virus's ability to infect and establish latency within B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CD20: This is a protein expressed on the surface of all B cells and is involved in B cell activation and proliferation. It is not used by EBV for cell entry.

 

Option C. CD19: This is a surface protein that acts as a co-receptor in B cell receptor signaling, but it is not directly involved in EBV entry.

 

Option D. CD23: This is the low-affinity receptor for IgE and does not play a role in EBV infection of B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

choices.text: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver tissue
Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis
White areas represent central hepatocytes

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is as shown below. Which among the following is true about it? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

The above picture shows centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis. The cut liver section, in which major blood vessels are visible, is notable for a variegated, mottled, red appearance (nutmeg liver) seen in right heart failure. The dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver which resembles the cut section of nutmeg. This occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

 

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes:

 

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein
  • Bile duct

 

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

 

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area
  • Zone 2 is the Intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the area closest to the central vein

 

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as nutmeg liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis: This is incorrect because the dark areas are where necrosis has occurred due to congestion, not viable tissue.

 

Option C. White areas represent central hepatocytes: The white areas represent periportal zones, which are generally healthier and not central hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Dark areas represent peri-portal hepatocytes: The dark areas actually represent the centrilobular regions where necrosis has occurred, not the periportal hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nutmeg liver is characterized by a mottled appearance, where dark areas represent necrosis due to chronic passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1665

questions.text:
Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Median nerve

2. Radial nerve

3. Tendon of biceps brachi

4. Brachial artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,4,3,2

 

Explanation:

 

The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:

 

1. Median nerve

2. Brachial artery

3. Tendon of biceps brachii

4. Radial nerve (Superficial Branch of radial nerve)

Mnemonic is MBBR
 

 

 

The cubital fossa is actually a triangular area located on the anterior aspect of the elbow, not the upper forearm. It is bounded by several structures, including:

 

  • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary
  • The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary
  • The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary
  • The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • The roof of cubital fossa contains Subcutaneous veins which are used for routine phlebotomy procedures. These veins are - median cubital vein, cephalic vein and basilic vein

 

The cubital fossa contains several important structures, including the brachial artery, radial nerve, and median nerve. It is a common site for blood draws and intravenous catheter placement due to the relatively superficial location of the structures and ease of access.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct anatomical sequencing of structures in the cubital fossa from medial to lateralmedian nerve, brachial artery, tendon of biceps brachii, and radial nerveis essential for both anatomical education and practical clinical applications.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is/are true about Crohns disease, in contrast to ulcerative colitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

  • Perianal fistulae: Crohns disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses, and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease. This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohns disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohns disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohns disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohns disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crohns disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahrs triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahrs triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

choices.text: The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of pterygium? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rate of recurrence is 95%

 

  • Pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue.
  • It is caused by prolonged exposure to UV rays, dry heat, etc.
  • It has three parts: head (apical part on the cornea, body (region between limbus and canthus), and cap (semilunar white infiltrate in front of the head).
  • Patients may experience itching and grittiness due to Dellen.
  • It can interfere with vision and induce astigmatism.
  • Stocker's line may be associated with pterygium, which is a linear deposition of iron seen in the corneal epithelium, anterior to the head of a pterygium.
  • The recurrence rate after simple surgical excision is around 80%.

 

 

  • Pterygium is of 2 types: 
    1. Progressive which is thick, fleshy, and vascular.
    2. Regressive which is thin, atrophic, and attenuated.
  • This condition can be treated symptomatically with tear substitutes for dry eye symptoms and patients are advised to avoid  exposure to sun.
  • Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred treatment to avoid recurrence.
  • The recurrence rate of pterygium is around 80% after simple surgical excision. Excision together with adjunctive therapies such as mitomycin C or 5-fluorouracil can reduce the risk of recurrence to approximately 10%.
  • Reported Recurrence rate after P.E.R.F.E.C.T technique is 1.6% (Cornelius CR. Recurrence Rate and Complications of Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a fibrovascular growth: This is accurate. Pterygium consists of fibrovascular tissue that can progressively invade the cornea.

 

Option C. The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap: This is true. The pterygium is typically described as having three parts: the head (which is the part that extends onto the cornea), the body (the main bulk of the growth), and the cap or leading edge.

 

Option D. Has progressive and regressive types: This is also true. Pterygium can be classified into progressive, which is active, vascular, and may encroach further onto the cornea, and regressive, which is typically less vascular and more fibrotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium's recurrence after surgical removal depends greatly on the surgical technique and the use of adjuvant therapies, not inherently 95% as previously thought. Effective management includes surgical excision combined with conjunctival autografts and adjuvant therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence significantly.

choices.text: Growth of 103 coliform in suprapubic sample
Growth of 105 coliform in voided urine sample
Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test

questions.text: Urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth of 105 coliform in voided urine sample

 

Explanation:

 

A urinary tract infection (UTI) in a pregnant woman is best defined by the growth of 10^5 coliforms per milliliter in a voided urine sample. This threshold is used to differentiate significant bacterial growth from contamination or a non-infectious presence of bacteria.

 

In pregnancy, the standard diagnostic method for UTI is a urine culture. A growth of 10^5 or more coliforms per milliliter in a properly collected voided urine sample is considered diagnostic for UTI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Growth of 103 coliform in suprapubic sample: Growth of 10^3 coliforms in a suprapubic sample is not a standard criterion for diagnosing UTI. Typically, suprapubic aspiration is used for more precise diagnoses, and lower thresholds may be acceptable due to reduced contamination risk compared to voided samples. However, for voided samples, the threshold is higher.

 

Option C. Frequency with dysuria with >3 WBC/HPF: Frequency with dysuria and >3 WBC/HPF indicates inflammation and possible infection but does not define a UTI by itself. The presence of WBCs in urine is a sign of inflammation or infection but is not specific for diagnosis.

 

Option D. Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test: Frequency with dysuria and positive nitrite and leucocyte esterase dipstick tests suggest a UTI but are not definitive. These tests are helpful as preliminary screening tools but are not as definitive as a quantitative urine culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as the growth of 10^5 coliforms in a voided urine sample.

 

Ref: Page no 348, DC Duttas Textbook of Obstetrics 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a germ cell tumor of the ovary? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Granulosa cell tumor

 

Granulosa cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor, not a germ cell tumor of the ovary.

 

Granulosa cell tumors are derived from the sex cord-stromal cells of the ovary. These tumors are characterized by the presence of Call-Exner bodies and coffee bean-shaped nuclei. They are estrogen-secreting functional tumors that may present as precocious puberty, endometrial hyperplasia, or post-menopausal bleeding. The marker for granulosa cell tumors is Inhibin B, and they are associated with FOXL2 mutation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yolk sac tumor: This is incorrect because yolk sac tumor, also known as endodermal sinus tumor, is a germ cell tumor of the ovary. 

 

Yolk sac tumor (Endodermal sinus tumor)

 

  • 2nd MC malignant GCT
  • MC malignant ovarian tumor presenting in <4years
  • Histology: presence of Schiller Duval Body/Glomeruloid body
  • Tumor markers: AFP +, 1 AT +ve

 

 

Option B. Dysgerminoma: This is incorrect because dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is the ovarian counterpart of testicular seminoma. 

  • Ovarian counterpart of seminoma
  • MC malignant GCT
  • Radiosensitive, chemo-sensitive tumor
  • Unilateral involvement mostly (85%)
  • Non-Functional tumor: hormones not secreted
  • Markers include transcription factors (OCT 3/4, NANOG, KiT) and enzymes (PLAP +, LDH, HCG but Normal AFP)

 

Option C. Choriocarcinoma: This is incorrect because choriocarcinoma can coexist with other germ cell tumors, as it can arise from either the ovary (germ cell origin) or the placenta (gestational trophoblastic disease)

 

  • It secretes beta-hCG, which serves as a tumor marker.
  • If it has ovarian origin: non- responsive to chemotherapy poor prognosis 
  • If it has placenta origin excellent responsive to chemotherapy good prognosis
  • Choriocarcinoma is known for early hematogenous spread and "cannon-ball" metastases to the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulosa cell tumor is classified as a sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary, not a germ cell tumor.
