questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition:(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Folate

 

  • Folate deficiency is the correct answer. Folate (also known as vitamin B9) plays a crucial role in DNA synthesis and repair. When there is a deficiency in folate, it can lead to the misincorporation of Uracil into DNA, causing DNA instability and other genetic abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12: A deficiency in vitamin B12 is not directly associated with the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B12 deficiency primarily affects red blood cell production and neurological functions.

 

Option B. B6: A deficiency in vitamin B6 is also not directly related to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms but does not cause Uracil incorporation into DNA.

 

Option D. Vit E: Vitamin E deficiency does not lead to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin E is primarily known for its antioxidant properties and its role in maintaining cell membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

 

Reference: Harpers 31st ed/pg- 333

choices.text: From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the tragus to the xiphisternum.
From the ala of the nose to the angle of the mandible to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the ear lobule to the umbilicus

questions.text: What is the appropriate technique to measure the placement of a nasogastric tube? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

 

This is the correct method. The nasogastric tube length is usually measured by estimating the distance from the tip of the nose, past the ear lobule (or the earlobe), and down to the xiphisternum (the point where the sternum meets the costal margin), also known as N-E-X rule. This method ensures that the tube is long enough to pass through the esophagus and reach the stomach without being too long to cause complications or too short to not be effective.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine the appropriate length of a nasogastric tube (also known as Ryle's tube) used for treating intestinal obstruction or providing nutritional support, the NEX method is commonly used, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum. The approximate length to be inserted is around 55 cm. The preferred position for inserting the Ryle's tube is in a sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

 

The proper positioning of the tube can be confirmed through auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by an abdominal radiograph. The ideal placement for an NG tube used for suction is within the stomach to avoid damage to the duodenum. In contrast, an NG feeding tube should be placed post-pyloric to reduce the risk of aspiration.

 

Indications for NG tube usage include gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric fluid, nutritional support, and medication administration. However, some absolute contraindications to NG tube insertion include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.

 

A tray of specialized instruments is used for nasogastric tube insertion, including a lubricating jelly, an NG tube, a syringe, and gloves, among others.

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

questions.text: An adult male patient in his 60s presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of haematuria. Upon examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass was observed, which was diagnosed as a low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. What is the recommended course of action for this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

 

For this patient diagnosed with bladder carcinoma, transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) is the most beneficial treatment option among the given choices. Based on the available evidence, there is no indication of muscle invasion or advanced cancer, suggesting that the most probable pathological stage is pTa - low grade non-muscle invasive cancer, for which TURBT followed by intravesical chemotherapy is the recommended treatment. TURBT is performed to pathologically stage the tumor and determine the appropriate course of treatment. Intravesical therapy using chemotherapy or immunotherapy is administered after TURBT to eradicate any residual cancer cells in the bladder lining, but it is not effective against cancers that have spread to muscle layers.

 

This is the correct answer. TURBT is a standard initial procedure for diagnosing and treating visible tumors, especially for low-grade, noninvasive disease. It involves removing the tumor from the bladder wall via the urethra. The stage of the bladder cancer can be determined by examining the sample removed during a TURBT, which aids in further treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Resection with ileal conduit: This is a more invasive surgery typically used for muscle invasive bladder cancers (radical cystectomy). An ileal conduit is a urinary diversion technique where urine is redirected through a piece of the intestine and out to a stoma on the abdomen.

 

Option C. Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction: This involves removing a part of the bladder affected by cancer. It's reserved for select patients where the tumor is localized and not near the urethral or ureteral openings. It might not be the first line of treatment for a 2x2 cm low-grade tumor.

 

Option D. Neo-adjuvant chemotherapy: This refers to chemotherapy given before a primary treatment in advanced cancers. In the case of bladder cancer, neo-adjuvant chemotherapy might be used before a surgery to shrink the tumor size or improve outcomes. However, for a low-grade, small tumor, it is not typically the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-muscle invasive bladder tumors (pTa/pT1): TUR-BT + Intravesical chemotherapy

 

Muscle invasive (pT2/pT3 and some pT4): Radical cystectomy + Ileal conduit

questions.text: Which mineral is important for sexual maturation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zinc

 

Explanation:

 

Zinc is the mineral most crucial for sexual maturation. It plays a significant role in several biological processes related to growth and development, particularly in the reproductive system. Zinc is essential for the stabilization of cell membranes and has anti-inflammatory properties. Moreover, zinc is crucial for the proper functioning and development of sperm, which directly links it to sexual maturation.

 

One of the key reasons zinc is important in sexual maturation is because of its role in the formation of zinc finger motifs. These motifs are a type of protein structure that binds to DNA and plays a vital role in gene expression, including genes involved in the development of sexual characteristics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Selenium is an essential trace element that plays a role in antioxidant defense and thyroid function. While it is important for general health, it is not as directly involved in sexual maturation as zinc.

 

Option B. Copper: Copper is important for various enzymatic reactions and the formation of red blood cells. Although it contributes to overall health, it is not specifically linked to sexual maturation.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium is critical for bone health and muscle function, but it does not have a direct role in sexual maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is the key mineral necessary for sexual maturation, particularly due to its role in the development and functioning of the reproductive system, including the formation of zinc finger motifs important for gene expression

questions.text: What is the optimal urine output for a patient who has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour

 

After a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is anticipated that the patient will have a normal urine output during the postoperative phase, which is 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour.

 

If converted into ml/day, approximately 1500 ml/day in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/minute, approximately 1 to 1.5 ml/minute in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/kg, approximately 12-36 ml/day in an avg. adult

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the forearm. Microscopic examination reveals the following features. Which of the following statements is wrong regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malignant tumor with frequent metastasis

 

The image shows the characteristic microscopic appearance of a schwannoma, which shows hypercellular areas (Antoni A) and hypocellular areas (Antoni B) with Verocay bodies (nuclear palisading). 

 

Schwannomas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from Schwann cells. 

 

Schwannomas are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and show nuclear palisading. 

 

The statement that it is a "malignant tumor with frequent metastasis" is incorrect because schwannomas are benign tumors with excellent prognosis and do not typically metastasize. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SCHWANNOMA

 

  • Peripheral Nerve sheath tumor
  • Benign
  • Arises from Schwann cells of Peripheral nerves or Cranial nerves (8th CN > 5th CN)

 

Risk factor:

 

  • NF2 gene mutation causes reduced merlin expression and increased cell multiplication
  • B/L schwannoma due to NF-2 gene mutation
  • Schwannoma arising from 8th CN was earlier called acoustic neuroma
  • Now called as vestibular schwannoma
  • C/F: SNHL, tinnitus, decreased corneal reflex
  • Diagnosed with MRI

 

Histology shows

 

  1. Hypercellular Antony 'A' area and hypocellular Antony 'B' area
    • Antony 'A' area: tumor cells arranged in fence-like pattern nuclear-free zones called verocay bodies
  2. Verocay body: Nuclear free area
  3. Presence of true palisading
  4. IHC shows S100+

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.text: A 45-year-old male worker presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, irritability, fatigue, and memory problems. He works in a battery manufacturing factory for the last 20 years. On further investigations, he is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption contributing to his condition in such industrial environments? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inhaled lead dust

 

  • In industrial environments such as battery manufacturing factories, the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption is through inhalation of lead dust.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead Poisoning is known as Plumbism, Saturnism or Painters Colic

 

  • Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painters Colic) is Gasoline/petrol/vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust
  • Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin

 

Additional Information

 

Clinical picture of lead poisoning:

 

  • Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
  • Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
  • Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
  • Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
  • Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
  • Lead encephalopathy
  • CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds

 

Diagnosis of lead poisoning:

 

 

A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).

 

Treatment: EDTA

questions.text: Under categorization of triage, the immediately life-threatening injuries would be classified as under the color-coded category: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Red

 

The triage system is used in disaster management to categorize victims based on the severity of their condition and the likelihood of survival. Immediate life-threatening injuries, where a person could die or develop severe complications if no intervention is made within 0 to 6 hours, are classified under the Red category. This category is designated for emergent cases that require immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This category is for urgent cases where intervention is needed within 6 to 24 hours, such as resuscitation or limb/life-saving surgery. Although these injuries are serious, they are not as immediately life-threatening as those in the Red category.

 

Option C. Green: This category is for non-urgent cases involving minor injuries like fractures, bruises, or lacerations. Patients in this category are ambulatory and can wait for treatment.

 

Option D. Black: This category is for patients who are either deceased or moribund (about to die). It represents the least priority in triage, as these patients have little to no chance of survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage Tagging system
